subject: US MARKET WRAP 15 March 2019: Stocks ignore weak manufacturing data to close higher, trade optimism cited
content:
* SNAP SHOT: Equities up, dollar down, Treasuries up, crude down.

* REAR VIEW: China eases foreign investment regulation; disappointing US manufacturing data, but positive UoM consumer sentiment; IEA monthly report

* NEXT WEEK: FOMC, BOE, NB, SNB, BCB, PMIs, UK activity data, Germany ZEW, CAD CPI.

* US MANUFACTURING: It was a miss for both the Empire Manufacturing survey, as well as the Manufacturing/IP data. Starting with the former, which heavily slipped to 3.7 from 8.8 (against a consensus 10.0). Pantheon's analysts said "the consensus forecast for an increase in the index was something of a head-scratcher, given the intense downward pressure on global manufacturing from China's sharp slowdown." The internals were mixed, with orders and shipments both falling, though employment put in a healthy rise. Pantheon noted that the data can be volatile, and a reversal next month might be a good bet. "China's PMI suggests that the Empire State index has further to fall over the next few months, but we expect something of a rebound from mid-year," adding "we reckon that the March Empire State numbers are consistent with a small increase in the national ISM manufacturing index." The manufacturing data was just as grim, falling for a second straight month, with autos dragging the most in both Jan and Feb. "In other words, a broad-based softening is underway, and we're sticking to our view that the sector will be in recession through mid-year," Pantheon said, pointing out that manufacturing accounts for only 12% of GDP, "so a short and relatively mild downturn in the sector is not going to pull the rest of the economy into the mire, but it will be a constraint on overall growth in both GDP and employment." The consultancy adds that headline industrial production rose in February due to the weather-related jump in utility output, "but this tells us nothing about the underlying state of the industrial economy: we are much more interested in the second straight decline in the value of business equipment production, which now points clearly to a clear dip, of about 2%, in the equipment investment component of Q1 GDP," and says that would be quite a turnaround from Q4, when spending rose at a 6.7% rate.

* TRADE: Overnight, Chinese lawmakers approved a new law on foreign investment, which replaces the existing rules regarding JVs and wholly owned foreign enterprises. UBS explains that "the rules are designed to ease foreign concerns about China's investment environment, especially as China and the US work to try and end a trade war." The new laws come into effect on Jan 1st, 2020.

* MICHIGAN SENTIMENT: The preliminary University of Michigan’s consumer sentiment index for March came in at 97.8, well above the expected 95.3, and a large 4 point increase from the previous 93.8. Elsewhere in the survey, the expectations component also blew over estimates, “supporting our view that consumer spending is poised to pick up,” Oxford Economics’ analysts note, “By historical standards, consumer sentiment remains elevated and is not far off from the 98.4 average recorded last year. Household fundamentals remain solid and are supported by job growth, firming wages, lower gas prices, and muted inflation. We look for consumption growth to average a healthy 2.5% in 2019.”

* BREXIT: A slew of Parliamentary votes this week saw UK lawmakers exert further pressure on Mrs May’s Brexit plans with the HoC still unable to agree on the UK’s route of departure from the EU. To recap events, Tuesday saw UK lawmakers reject PM May’s Brexit plan for a second time after AG Cox was unable to alter his opinion on the legal risks surrounding the UK’s ability to unilaterally leave the Irish backstop. Thereafter, Wednesday saw UK lawmakers approve a motion which called on the Government to rule out a no-deal in any scenario before accepting the motion to extend the Article 50 process beyond 29th March on Thursday. With May’s deal still unable to command a majority in Parliament, AG Cox attempted to win over Tory Brexiteers and the DUP with new legal advice which would state Britain will be able to break off from backstop under terms of the Vienna Convention. However, reports towards the end of the week suggested that these efforts were unsuccessful. As such, attention now turns to the prospect of further Parliamentary votes and Thursday/Friday’s European Council meeting. Before the EU Council meeting, there have been suggestions that May could put her deal to Parliament for a third time (MV3) with the PM hopeful that Brexiteers in her own party might be tempted to back her plan amid fears of further delays to Brexit or the possibility of no Brexit at all.

* WTI (J9) SETTLED USD 0.09 LOWER AT USD 58.52/BBL, BRENT (K9) SETTLED USD 0.07 LOWER AT USD 67.16/BBL. Crude prices ended the week in a similar manner to Thursday, choppy, with Brent paring back gains made at the beginning of the week before bouncing into settlement. Underpinning the early swing lower was the monthly oil report from the International Energy Agency, “The agency said that OPEC members would be more than capable of mitigating the impact of unplanned supply shortages. On the other hand, it is worth noting that the IEA foresees some 220,000 bpd of global stock draw in the second quarter,” analysts at PVM noted. Elsewhere, Russia’s Energy Minister Novak said it is too early to decide whether the OPEC & Non-OPEC output cut deal should be extended, pouring some water on to the growing expectations of a sustained supply contraction. Baker Hughes Rig Count (15 Mar): total rigs -1 at 1026, oil rigs -1 at 833, gas rigs unchanged at 193.

* SPX +0.49% at 2822, NDX +0.9% at 7307, DJI +0.6% at 25848. SECTORS: Energy -0.1%, Materials +0.2%, Industrials -0.2%, Cons Discretionary +0.7%, Cons Staples +0.5%, Healthcare +0.5%, Financials +0.6%, Tech 1.2%, Telecoms 0.0%, Utilities 0.5%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Adobe (ADBE) dipped lower on Friday, despite beating top and bottom line estimates, after lowering next quarter’s guidance. Oracle (ORCL) nosedived on the open following some pessimistic guidance, but soon reversed the losses. Facebook (FB) was an underperformer on a long-time executive departure. Ulta Beauty (ULTA) and Broadcom (AVGO) both surged following strong earnings reports. Amazon (AMZN) opened higher after an upgrade at Keybanc, citing increased profitability. Zillow Group (ZG) suffered from a downgrade at Barclays, saying “the worst is yet to come”. Newell Brands (NWL) opened higher following the announcement of its CEO of 10 years retiring, with Wells Fargo analysts commenting bullishly/savagely, “It’s hard to see how things can get any worse.” Apple (AAPL) supported indices to end the week, where a court ruling ordered Qualcomm (QCOM) to pay Apple USD 1bln in rebate fines; Apple also went publicly on the offensive saying that Spotify (SPOT) “wants everything for free” after the music streaming service filed a lawsuit against it.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) SETTLED 8+ TICKS AT HIGHER 122-31. Treasuries caught a bid on Friday, in a session influenced by both flows and macro themes, where against the grain, equities made healthy gains. The T-plex gained momentum going into the US equity open, with CTA short covering and real money and hedge fund buying kickstarting the rally, also supported by a gloomy outlook from the BoJ on top of North Korea woes, and was exacerbated by the both disappointing Empire Manufacturing survey and Manufacturing/IP data. Once equities opened in the green, Treasuries lost their tailwind as traders took their profits. The curve flattened going into settlement with the belly’s yields falling the most, where the 2s/10s flattened by 2bps. However, spreads in the belly to  long-end still remain at their steepest levels in months. 

* USD: The Greenback looks all set to end the week on the back foot, with the index pegged towards the bottom of a 97.461-96.371 range having kicked off nearer the apex and just a fraction under 97.400. It has not been all one way traffic, but sub-forecast US data, like CPI, IP, retail sales and durable goods (latter 2 on balance rather than headline terms) have thwarted fleeting recoveries along with strength in major (and EM) currency counterparts and the DXY has been on a downward trajectory overall.

* NZD/AUD: The Kiwi and Aussie have both been volatile within 0.6873-0.6783 and 0.7098-23 respective ranges vs their US namesake, but the Aud/Nzd cross has continued to steadily decline (from 1.0365 to sub-1.0300 at one stage) in line with the bearish post-RBA tone prompted by heightened and more widespread dovish calls. That aside, the Antipodean Dollars have been fluctuating with wider risk sentiment, domestic data/surveys and external developments with particular focus on China where a disappointing trade balance has been countered by some positive noises regarding trade negotiations with the US and PBoC/NPC pledges to support the economy as it faces pronounced downside risks. Nzd/Usd and Aud/Usd currently around 0.6850 and 0.7085.

* GBP: Some relative calm after 3 extremely stormy days, but not without incident as the Pound suffered an abrupt early sell-off before stopping the rot ahead of 1.3200 and circa 0.8575 vs the Usd and Eur respectively. Brexit has been by far the biggest driver and focus, with UK Parliament kicking off a series of votes by rejecting PM May’s Withdrawal Agreement for a 2nd time on Tuesday, and precipitating votes on a no deal, which was also ruled out, and finally whether to extend Article 50 beyond March 29 on Thursday, with the latter approved. Sterling typically traded a tad stronger before and after each HoC debate and subsequent vote, which were complicated by various amendments also under consideration, and especially when the no deal or cliff edge scenario was turned down by MPs, although technically and legally still possible. However, Cable has faded from best levels within 1.3383-1.2947 parameters to sit circa 1.3270 and Eur/Gbp is midway between 0.8575-25 (and 0.8675-0.8475 for the week as a whole) as the reality sets in that the EU still has to ratify any request to delay Brexit and wants a concrete reason why, while insisting that the revised deal with additional assurances is the only one available. On that note, a 3rd Meaningful Vote is pencilled in for Tuesday next week, ahead of the 2-day EU Summit on Thursday and Friday and the Government is in talks with the DUP to try and hammer out a compromise that might get majority support this time.

* EUR: The single currency has extended its post-ECB rebound, partly on the aforementioned generally soft Dollar, and just carved out a minor new high for the week around 1.1345 having triggered hefty option expiry interest just above 1.1300 for the 2nd consecutive session. The Eur has been relatively resilient towards more marked downward revisions to 2019 German GDP forecasts with the aid of some better data and technically on a breach of several key resistance levels.

* JPY/CHF: Both ending Friday’s EU session on the front foot vs the Usd, but the Yen still net weaker on the week after some disappointing Japanese data and a dovish BoJ policy meeting, albeit the latter widely expected. Usd/Jpy is right on the 200 DMA at 111.44 vs a high of 111.89 and 110.86 low, while the Franc is nudging its best levels just below parity from almost 1.0100 at the other extreme after less deflationary Swiss producer/import price data and ahead of next week’s quarterly SNB policy review.

* CAD: The Loonie failed to get a boost from firmer than forecast Canadian manufacturing sales, as oil prices retreated from new multi-month highs and Usd/Cad bounced off chart support below 1.3300 again. However, the Cad remains some 100 pips off worst levels vs its US rival ahead of March’s FOMC that is expected to compound the more dovish shift via details of an earlier wind down of QT.

* SEK/NOK: Strong performances for the Scandi Crowns on balance with decent gains made vs the Euro as the Riksbank continued to downplay soft Swedish inflation and firmer than consensus Norwegian economic inputs underpinned Norges Bank rate hike prospects for next week. Eur/Sek consolidating a clean break of 10.5000 and likewise Eur/Nok its breach of 9.7000.

* COMING-UP: Monday: No Tier 1 Data Releases. Speakers – ECB’s Praet. Tuesday: Data – Australian Home Price Index; UK Employment Data & Average Earnings; German ZEW; US Factory Orders. Speakers – Riksbank’s Skingsley. Earnings – FedEx. Wednesday: Data – UK CPI; New Zealand GDP. Events – FOMC Rate Decision. Speakers – Fed’s Powell. Auctions – German EUR 4.0bln 0.0% Bobl. Earnings – BMW, Carnival, Micro Technologies. Thursday: Data – Australian Employment; UK Retail Sales; US Jobless Claims, Philly Fed Business Index, Leading Index Change; Japanese CPI. Events – SNB, Norges Bank & BoE Rate Decision. Auctions – French EUR 7.5-9.0bln 0% 2022, 2024 & 2025 auction. Earnings – HeidelbergCement, Enel, Nike. Friday: Data – French, German, EZ & US Markit Manufacturing, Services & Composite PMI (Flash); Canadian CPI, Retail Sales; US Existing Home Sales. Speakers – Fed’s Bostic, ECB’s Mersch. Click here for full briefing.

* Central Bank Weekly: Previewing FOMC, SNB, BOE, Norges, RBA mins, BCB, CBR. Click here for full briefing.

content: Another sub-forecast US macro release has underpinned bonds, but only for the latest leg of a firm rebound that started even before the earlier Empire State survey let alone the soft ip and manufacturing output. Nevertheless, Gilts and Bunds have just posted new intraday highs at 127.13 and 164.45 (+45 and +32 ticks vs -7 and ticks at one stage) and Bunds eclipsed their previous Eurex session peak by a few ticks at 164., as US Treasuries continue to unwind recent bear-steepening amidst a raft of buying from various account types, spread liquidations, stops and upside call option-related hedging. Back to the 10 year EU benchmarks, if the am downturn was indirectly or remotely connected a pre-quadruple witching squeeze in cash bourses then the inverse link has been severed, but the Usd remains under pressure with the DXY back down near 96.500 and fresh session lows.

DJIA

  • Apple (AAPL), Qualcomm (QCOM) – A California judge has determined that Qualcomm must pay Apple just under USD 1bln in rebate payments as they were "part of a business agreement between the two companies." (MacRumours)
  • Apple (AAPL), Spotify (SPOT) – Following Spotify filing a lawsuit against Apple for claiming its app store fees make it harder to compete with, Apple replied saying that Spotify “wants all the benefits of a free app without being free.” (Newswires)
  • Boeing (BA) – The aerospace co. is reportedly still producing its 737 MAX jets at full capacity, in the midst of customers pulling orders, with Malaysia Airlines being the latest, where it is reviewing an order for 25 jets. NY Times reports that the captain of the Ethiopian Airlines crash reported trouble soon after take-off, where he said the plane was accelerating to abnormally high speeds. Elsewhere, families of the 157 victims will likely be able to sue Boeing in US courts for large amounts of cash. (Newswires/NYT)

(Newswires)

Elsewhere, BGR reports that the co. may be developing foldable Pixel phones, where software updates reveal capability for foldable phones. (FT/BGR)
  • Facebook (FB) – The social media co.’s Chief Product Officer Chris Cox is leaving, after more than a decade at Facebook. (Newswires)

Separately, the co. unveiled its new Model Y SUV vehicle, which has a starting price of USD 39,000; the co. sees the more expensive models being delivered in Fall 2020, but the basic model not delivered till Spring 2021. Elsewhere, CEO Elon Musk has not given up plans to launch in India, following regulatory hurdles in the region. Morgan Stanley analysts Adam Jones says the new Model Y will likely “cannibalise” the model 3. (Newswires)

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 15th March 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Major European indices trade positively as US-China trade optimism continues from Asia.
  • UK AG Cox is attempting to win over Brexiteers and DUP with new legal advice; however, Cox’s efforts have been rejected by Brexit supporting lawmakers.
  • Dollar underperforms major counterparts, particularly NZD & GBP
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US NY Fed Manufacturing, US Manufacturing Output & Industrial Production, and Quadruple Witching

 

ASIA  

Asian stocks traded mostly positive across the board as US-China trade optimism helped the region shake off the negative lead from the US, where sentiment was subdued by growth concerns following recent discouraging data from China and the reported delay in the Trump-Xi summit. ASX 200 (-0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.8%) were mixed with upside in Australia capped as weakness in mining names and financials offset the continued outperformance in energy, while the Japanese benchmark coat-tailed on recent currency moves. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.0%) were higher as overnight trade-related news flow spurred optimism including comments from President Trump that we will have news regarding a China trade deal in the next 3-4 weeks and although he included a ‘one way or the other’ caveat, he suggested that people will be talking about it for a long time and that China has been very reasonable. In addition, Chinese officials also contributed to the trade hopes after the NPC approved Foreign Investment law reforms dealing with forced tech transfers and IP theft which is seen as an attempt to appease US concerns, while Chinese Premier Li noted that China can use reserve requirements as well as interest rates to support the economy and confirmed VAT tax cuts will begin from next month. Finally, 10yr JGBs were relatively flat with demand dampened as focus centred on riskier assets and after the BoJ policy announcement proved to be a non-event in which it maintained policy settings and downgraded assessments on exports and output as expected.

PBoC injected CNY 20bln via 7-day reverse repos for a net weekly injection of CNY 20bln vs. last week's CNY 220bln net drain. PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7167 (Prev. 6.7009). (Newswires)

US President Trump said we will have news on China trade deal in the next 3-4 weeks one way or the other, while he added that China has been very responsible and very reasonable. In related news, there were also earlier reports which suggested China was proposing tying in an official state visit by President Xi to a US trade deal (Newswires)

Chinese Vice Premier Liu He conducted a phone call with US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and Trade Representative Lighthizer in which China and US were said to have made further substantive progress on trade discussions, while Mnuchin had earlier commented that he is pleased with progress on trade talks with China and expects elements of Chinese trade talks to be resolved in the near future. (Newswires)

Chinese Premier Li said China faces new downward pressure but added they will not let growth slip out of reasonable range and that China can use reserve requirements as well as interest rates to support the economy. Premier Li added China will cut VAT tax from April 1st and will tighten its belt due to tax cuts, while he hopes US-China trade talks achieve results. (Newswires)

China NPC approved foreign investment law reforms which deal with forced technology transfers and intellectual property protections which will take effect from January next year. However, the American Chamber of Commerce in China said tweaks to FDI law only addresses small concerns. (Newswires)

Chinese House Prices (Feb) Y/Y 10.4% (Prev. 10.0%). (Newswires)

BoJ kept monetary policy settings unchanged with NIRP held at -0.10% and 10yr JGB target at around 0% as expected, while it also maintained forward guidance of keeping rates at current extremely low levels for extended period. Furthermore, the BoJ stated that Japan’s economy is likely to continue expanding moderately despite effects of overseas slowdown but lowered its assessment on exports and output. (Newswires)

Governor Kuroda says momentum towards 2% inflation target is maintained. (Newswires)

- Overseas developments will effect Japan for some time but the economy remains in moderate expansion

- The BoJ is aware of a slowdown in exports and production but the domestic economy remains firm

NORTH AMERICA

US Senate voted 59-41 in favour of the proposal to reject President Trump’s national emergency declaration on the US-Mexico border, although President Trump tweeted “VETO!” shortly after. (BBC)

BoC Deputy Governor Wilkins said underlying vulnerabilities means there will still be headwinds to growth even after trade war is resolved, while she added that interest rate changes will have stronger impact then in the past as people are more indebted and that high debt could mean move to neutral could be longer. (Newswires)

US President Trump and Chinese President Xi may meet in mid-April or later; US Secretary of State Pompeo. (Newswires)

UK/EU            

UK Attorney General Cox is reportedly attempting to win over Tory Brexiteers and the DUP with new legal advice which will state Britain will be able to break off from backstop under terms of the Vienna Convention. (Telegraph) Following this, Brexit supporting lawmakers have rejected UK Attorney Cox's additional legal opinion on UK PM May's divorce deal assurances. (Times)

EU's Verhofstadt said EU can only agree to Brexit delay if parliament makes it clear what it will support. In related news, ITV's Peston suggested If UK PM asked EU for an extension to the Article 50 process, EU might not make the decision at the 21st March summit and may schedule an emergency EU summit for a few days before the 29 March exit date. (Newswires/ITV)

Irish Finance Minister says that DUP is engaging intensively with the UK Government. (Newswires)

ECB's Rehn states that the ECB should conduct a systematic review of policy strategy as unconventional tools so far have failed to have the desired effect. (Newswires)

- Central banks ability to influence inflation may have eroded

- Interdependence of growth and inflation seem to have weakened, eroding ECB impact on prices via demand

GEOPOLITICAL

North Korea is considering suspending nuclear discussions with US and does not intend to yield to US demands, while leader Kim is set to make an official announcement of his position, according to the Deputy Foreign Minister Choe Son Hui. Elsewhere other reports also noted that Kim Jong Un may rethink moratorium on missile launches and that the US threw away a golden opportunity at the Hanoi summit. (TASS/AP)

EQUITIES

Major European indices have remained firm after opening with mild gains [Euro Stoxx 50 +1.4%], continuing from overnight where risk sentiment improved following US-China trade optimism. Sectors are largely in the green, although there is some mild underperformance in healthcare names. Weighed on simultaneously by a downgrade at Citi Group and reports that the Co’s India operations are the focus of a Singapore probe are Wirecard (-9.1%) who are at the bottom of the Stoxx 600, although this was later refuted by the Co. Elsewhere, and towards the top of the Dax, are BMW (+1.0%) who have been in focus after warning of headwinds impacting the sector and reported FY18 revenue slightly above expectations and EBIT margin above target; which subsequently led to short-term volatility in Co. shares. Separately, UBS (-0.9%) are in the red after their annual trade report where the Co. stated that provisions for litigation, regulatory and other matters reduced FY18 operating profit before tax and net profit for shareholders by USD 382mln.

FX

NZD/AUD - The Kiwi has rebounded firmly from lows close to 0.6800 vs its US counterpart after a more conciliatory tone from both sides of the US-China trade divide overnight compared to reports circling on Thursday highlighting ongoing issues that remain unresolved and have rolled back the likely date of a Trump-Xi official signing-off Summit. Nzd/Usd is currently towards the top of a 0.6858-24 range, but hampered somewhat by cross-winds as Aud/Nzd consolidates recovery gains above 1.0300 and the Aussie also reclaims lost ground against the Usd to retest resistance ahead of 0.7100.

CAD/EUR/GBP - Also benefiting from the Greenback’s broad loss of momentum as the DXY failed to sustain yesterday’s more bullish technical impulses beyond 96.821 and closer to the 97.000 handle. The Loonie is also deriving some impetus from steadier oil prices and could get a helping hand from Canadian manufacturing sales if expectations for a rebound are confirmed. Usd/Cad is hovering just above 1.3300 and back to within striking distance of the 200 DMA. Meanwhile, the single currency continues to try and establish/build a base on the 1.1300 handle, but resistance around the recent 1.1340 high and mega option expiry interest remain formidable barriers to overcome, with 1.9 bn at the big figure and 3.3 bn running off between 1.305-25 at Friday’s NY cut. Turning to the Pound, and a bout of selling saw Cable test underlying bids/support ahead of 1.3200, while Eur/Gbp spiked to 0.8575, but with little obvious in the way of a catalyst and for once relative quiet on the Brexit front the relatively rapid moves have subsequently reversed to circa 1.3275 and 0.8525 respectively.

JPY/CHF - Both relatively flat vs the Dollar and still rangebound, as Usd/Jpy meanders from 111.90 to 111.50 and just above the 200 DMA (111.44) in wake of a dovish BoJ policy meeting, as widely anticipated. Decent expiries from 111.50-65 (1.1 bn) could underpin the headline pair, while 112.00 and a Fib at 112.08 are keeping the upside in check. The Franc is even more contained within 1.0045-20 and vs the Eur around 1.1350 ahead of next week’s quarterly SNB policy review.

SEK/NOK - The Scandi Crowns looks set to end the week on the front foot having regained the initiative over the Euro and crossed psychological/technical levels, and with some added backing from a US bank advocating long positions via the Eur/Sek cross and Usd/Nok -  see our headline feed for more details.

FIXED INCOME

No physical or even market rumblings about any asset-switching, but a recent advance in EU stocks has resulted in or coincided with a broader and more pronounced pull-back in core debt futures. Bunds are now testing the water around 164.00 and Gilts are 35 ticks off best levels at 126.60, albeit only 7 ticks below par as US Treasuries drift down sit essentially flat or a tad weaker at marginal new overnight session lows. No doubt short term technicals are also impacting, but bonds appear to be spellbound by equities into quadruple-witching.

COMMODITIES

Brent and WTI prices are softer heading into the weekend, a sharp decline this morning saw prices drop significantly below the day’s ranges, with no significant fundamental news behind this. This morning saw the release of the IEA’s monthly report, which maintained the 2019 global oil demand growth forecasts at 1.4mln BPD, which has been supported by strong non-OECD consumption. IEA state that OPEC crude production in Feb was 30.68mln BPD, a decrease of 240k BPD; due to losses in Venezuela and lower output from both Saudi Arabia and Iraq. Adding that preliminary data for February points to a sharp drop in inventories. Looking ahead on the calendar sees the Baker Hughes rig count at 17:00 GMT due to the US time change, where total rigs decreased by 11 to 1027.

Gold (+0.4%) is firmer in spite of the improvement in risk sentiment, potentially due to the yellow metal retracing some of yesterday’s decline where it dropped below USD 1300/oz, for reference spot gold is currently trading around USD 1302/oz. Separately, Indian gold demand may drop in May due to restrictions surrounding cash movement an Industry Official has reported. Elsewhere, copper prices improved overnight on the risk sentiment.

Russian Energy Minister Novak says it is too early to decide whether OPEC & Non-OPEC output cut deal should be extended, and that he will attende the JMMC meeting in Baku. (Newswires)

IEA Monthly Report: maintain forecast of global oil demand growth for 2019 at 1.4mln BPD, has been supported by strong non-OECD consumption. (Newswires)

- Global oil production fell by 340 K BPD in February as OPEC and non-OPEC cuts deepened.

- OPEC crude oil production in February dropped by 240k BPD, to 30.68mln BPD

- Global refining throughput returned to growth, with 1Q19 expected to be up 0.8mln BPD Y/Y

- OECD commercial oil stocks rose 8.6mln BPD on the month in January to their highest level since November 2017

- Brent futures reached a four-month high, above $67/bbl, in mid-March on reduced production from OPEC

- Non-OPEC oil output growth will slow from 2018 record of 2.8mln VPD to around 1.8mln BPD in 2019

- Preliminary Feb data suggest a sharp drop in stocks

Quadruple Witching Schedule
content:
10:15 FTSE 100 Mar’19 Futures and Options Expiry

subject: US President Trump and Chinese President Xi may meet in mid-April or later; US Secretary of State Pompeo
FX Morning Colour: high beta, risk and commodity currencies back in the ascendency
content:
NZD/AUD

The Kiwi has rebounded firmly from lows close to 0.6800 vs its US counterpart after a more conciliatory tone from both sides of the US-China trade divide overnight compared to reports circling on Thursday highlighting ongoing issues that remain unresolved and have rolled back the likely date of a Trump-Xi official signing-off Summit. Nzd/Usd is currently towards the top of a 0.6858-24 range, but hampered somewhat by cross-winds as Aud/Nzd consolidates recovery gains above 1.0300 and the Aussie also reclaims lost ground against the Usd to retest resistance ahead of 0.7100.

CAD/EUR/GBP

Also benefiting from the Greenback’s broad loss of momentum as the DXY failed to sustain yesterday’s more bullish technical impulses beyond 96.821 and closer to the 97.000 handle. The Loonie is also deriving some impetus from steadier oil prices and could get a helping hand from Canadian manufacturing sales if expectations for a rebound are confirmed. Usd/Cad is hovering just above 1.3300 and back to within striking distance of the 200 DMA. Meanwhile, the single currency continues to try and establish/build a base on the 1.1300 handle, but resistance around the recent 1.1340 high and mega option expiry interest remain formidable barriers to overcome, with 1.9 bn at the big figure and 3.3 bn running off between 1.305-25 at Friday’s NY cut. Turning to the Pound, and a bout of selling saw Cable test underlying bids/support ahead of 1.3200, while Eur/Gbp spiked to 0.8575, but with little obvious in the way of a catalyst and for once relative quiet on the Brexit front the relatively rapid moves have subsequently reversed to circa 1.3275 and 0.8525 respectively.

JPY/CHF 

Both relatively flat vs the Dollar and still rangebound, as Usd/Jpy meanders from 111.90 to 111.50 and just above the 200 DMA (111.44) in wake of a dovish BoJ policy meeting, as widely anticipated. Decent expiries from 111.50-65 (1.1 bn) could underpin the headline pair, while 112.00 and a Fib at 112.08 are keeping the upside in check. The Franc is even more contained within 1.0045-20 and vs the Eur around 1.1350 ahead of next week’s quarterly SNB policy review.

SEK/NOK

The Scandi Crowns looks set to end the week on the front foot having regained the initiative over the Euro and crossed psychological/technical levels, and with some added backing from a US bank advocating long positions via the Eur/Sek cross and Usd/Nok -  see our headline feed for more details.

subject: UK debt and STIR futures confirm to recovery tone and prolonged Brexit uncertainty
content: Gilts gapped up ¼ point on their return to Liffe and have had an early look at offers/resistance ahead of 127.00, while Short Sterling contracts advanced 1.5 ticks at best before drifting back in wake of the 3rd and final series of votes in Parliament that resulted in a rare, but somewhat hollow victory for PM May as MPs approved extending the Article 50 deadline beyond March 29th. The decision means more time to sort out a mutually acceptable WA, but also an even longer period of uncertainty and another MV that still seems destined to end in rejection. Back to bonds, the 10 year benchmark has lost momentum and drifted back to 126.77, and in doing so have filled a gap on some charts awaiting further directional leads.

content: The 10 year German debt future is attempting to nudge a bit higher following a tentative open, and has extended gains to 25 ticks from yesterday’s 164.13 close, with US Treasuries also inching a tad higher having set a mildly firmer tone initially. However, this looks largely consolidative following recent declines in core debt and curve steepening, with Bunds still respecting the broad boundaries laid down since the post-ECB rally and retreat from new contract highs. Ahead, final Italian and pan Eurozone inflation data, plus Italian industrial orders and sales alongside a scheduled speech by ECB’s Rehn.

In addition, Chinese officials also contributed to the trade hopes after the NPC approved Foreign Investment law reforms dealing with forced tech transfers and IP theft which is seen as an attempt to appease US concerns, while Chinese Premier Li noted that China can use reserve requirements as well as interest rates to support the economy and confirmed VAT tax cuts will begin from next month.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 15th March 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian stocks traded mostly positive across the board as US-China trade optimism helped the region shake off the negative lead from the US
  • BoJ kept monetary policy settings unchanged with NIRP held at -0.10% and 10yr JGB target at around 0% as expected
  • US President Trump said we will have news on China trade deal in the next 3-4 weeks one way or the other
  • UK lawmakers voted (412 vs 202) to accept the government's motion to extend the Article 50 process beyond 29th March
  •  

ASIA-PAC

Asian stocks traded mostly positive across the board as US-China trade optimism helped the region shake off the negative lead from the US, where sentiment was subdued by growth concerns following recent discouraging data from China and the reported delay in the Trump-Xi summit. ASX 200 (-0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.8%) were mixed with upside in Australia capped as weakness in mining names and financials offset the continued outperformance in energy, while the Japanese benchmark coat-tailed on recent currency moves. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.5%) were higher as overnight trade-related news flow spurred optimism including comments from President Trump that we will have news regarding a China trade deal in the next 3-4 weeks and although he included a ‘one way or the other’ caveat, he suggested that people will be talking about it for a long time and that China has been very reasonable. In addition, Chinese officials also contributed to the trade hopes after the NPC approved Foreign Investment law reforms dealing with forced tech transfers and IP theft which is seen as an attempt to appease US concerns, while Chinese Premier Li noted that China can use reserve requirements as well as interest rates to support the economy and confirmed VAT tax cuts will begin from next month. Finally, 10yr JGBs were relatively flat with demand dampened as focus centred on riskier assets and after the BoJ policy announcement proved to be a non-event in which it maintained policy settings and downgraded assessments on exports and output as expected.

PBoC injected CNY 20bln via 7-day reverse repos for a net weekly injection of CNY 20bln vs. last week's CNY 220bln net drain. PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7167 (Prev. 6.7009). (Newswires)

US President Trump said we will have news on China trade deal in the next 3-4 weeks one way or the other, while he added that China has been very responsible and very reasonable. In related news, there were also earlier reports which suggested China was proposing tying in an official state visit by President Xi to a US trade deal (Newswires)

Chinese Vice Premier Liu He conducted a phone call with US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and Trade Representative Lighthizer in which China and US were said to have made further substantive progress on trade discussions, while Mnuchin had earlier commented that he is pleased with progress on trade talks with China and expects elements of Chinese trade talks to be resolved in the near future. (Newswires)

Chinese Premier Li said China faces new downward pressure but added they will not let growth slip out of reasonable range and that China can use reserve requirements as well as interest rates to support the economy. Premier Li added China will cut VAT tax from April 1st and will tighten its belt due to tax cuts, while he hopes US-China trade talks achieve results. (Newswires)

China NPC approved foreign investment law reforms which deal with forced technology transfers and intellectual property protections which will take effect from January next year. However, the American Chamber of Commerce in China said tweaks to FDI law only addresses small concerns. (Newswires)

Chinese House Prices (Feb) Y/Y 10.4% (Prev. 10.0%). (Newswires)

BoJ kept monetary policy settings unchanged with NIRP held at -0.10% and 10yr JGB target at around 0% as expected, while it also maintained forward guidance of keeping rates at current extremely low levels for extended period. Furthermore, the BoJ stated that Japan’s economy is likely to continue expanding moderately despite effects of overseas slowdown but lowered its assessment on exports and output. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK lawmakers voted (412 vs 202) to accept the government's motion to extend the Article 50 process beyond 29th March. Furthermore, lawmakers rejected Amendments E (302 for vs. 318 against) which called on PM May to seek an Article 50 extension to avoid leaving the EU on 29th March without a deal and to provide parliamentary time for the HoC to find a majority for a different approach. Parliament also rejected Amendment I which proposed Parliament force a series of indicative votes on 20th March on the next Brexit steps and rejected Amendment H (85 for vs 334 against) which would have instructed UK PM May to request an extension of Article 50 of sufficient length for a referendum to be legislated for and held with options for leaving on terms determined by parliament or staying in the EU. (Newswires)

UK PM May spokesperson said May has given commitment to bring forward legislative measure required to change the exit date in law. The spokesperson also stated that A50 delay would not result in a transition period extension if a deal is reached but added that the government is still preparing for no-deal and that Parliament will discuss next steps on March 25th if Brexit deal fails. (Newswires)

UK Attorney General Cox is reportedly attempting to win over Tory Brexiteers and the DUP with new legal advice which will state Britain will be able to break off from backstop under terms of the Vienna Convention. (Telegraph)

EU's Verhofstadt said EU can only agree to Brexit delay if parliament makes it clear what it will support. In related news, ITV's Peston suggested If UK PM asked EU for an extension to the Article 50 process, EU might not make the decision at the 21st March summit and may schedule an emergency EU summit for a few days before the 29 March exit date. (Newswires/ITV) 

FX

In FX markets, the DXY was indecisive and predominantly stuck within the prior US session’s tight range amid a mixed picture across its major counterparts in which EUR/USD nursed losses after finding support around the 1.3000 level and GBP/USD consolidated following this week’s parliamentary bedlam. Furthermore, brief support was seen in GBP on reports Attorney General Cox is attempting to win over Tory Brexiteers and the DUP with new legal advice that Britain will be able to break off from the backstop under terms of the Vienna Convention, which also followed parliamentary approval of the government's motion to extend the Article 50 process. Elsewhere, antipodeans were marginally positive as they benefitted from their high-beta characteristics, as well as the improved risk tone which also helped validate Gotobi demand advocates in USD/JPY although some of the moves were later faded on news that North Korea is considering suspending nuclear discussions with the US.

BoC Deputy Governor Wilkins said underlying vulnerabilities means there will still be headwinds to growth even after trade war is resolved, while she added that interest rate changes will have stronger impact then in the past as people are more indebted and that high debt could mean move to neutral could be longer. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were somewhat mixed with WTI crude futures flat as prices took a breather from its recent rally as upside was limited by demand side factors including ongoing growth concerns and after global oil demand growth was cut in the latest OPEC monthly report. Nonetheless, prices remained at multi-month highs in the aftermath of this week’s supportive inventory data and prospects of an output cut extension, while Goldman Sachs also affirmed a bullish view on prices. Elsewhere, gold attempted to make the most of a lacklustre greenback and nursed some of its recent losses before it met resistance at the USD 1300/oz level, and copper also staged a mild recovery as risk appetite improved during the session.

Saudi and Russia energy delegates are to meet in Baku on Sunday. (Newswires)

US extended sanctions waivers for Venezuelan-controlled Citgo by over a year. (Newswires)

Goldman Sachs said it sees scope for Brent to rally to above USD 70/bbl in the near-term as it sees current fundamentals to tighten physical markets and in turn driving the Brent forward curve into further backwardation. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

North Korea is considering suspending nuclear discussions with US and does not intend to yield to US demands, while leader Kim is set to make an official announcement of his position, according to the Deputy Foreign Minister Choe Son Hui. Elsewhere other reports also noted that Kim Jong Un may rethink moratorium on missile launches and that the US threw away a golden opportunity at the Hanoi summit. (TASS/AP)

 

GLOBAL NEWS

New Zealand police reportedly have 4 suspects in custody including a suspected shooter following a deadly attack on a Mosque involving multiple fatalities at 2 locations in Christchurch, New Zealand. (Newswires)

US

Treasuries edged slightly lower on Thursday, with the T-plex ran into the session on a downward path where hedge funds were reported to be selling at the long-end, causing the curve to steepen. Although this was supported by CTAs covering their shorts just before the US equity open, with some block buyers in the front end, but this trend halted as Europeans began leaving their desks, keeping any price rallies limited. Going into the settlement, yields rose across the curve, long-end saw yields rose the most prolific with the 30-year up by c. 3.5bps. Spreads also widened further, where the 5s/30s at the greatest in 13 months and the 2s/30s greatest in 9 months. US T-note futures (M9) settled 5 ticks lower at 122-22+.

US Senate voted 59-41 in favour of the proposal to reject President Trump’s national emergency declaration on the US-Mexico border, although President Trump tweeted “VETO!” shortly after. (BBC)

PRE-MARKET INDIA STOCK NEWS: India’s Department of Telecommunications is invoking bank guarantees to recover Reliance Communications’ latest spectrum dues
content:
IDBI Bank (IDBI IS) - RBI classified the Co. as private lender after LIC took control of it which reports note could result in a rating downgrade and higher cost of funding. (ET)

Reliance Communications (RCOM IS) - India’s Department of Telecommunications is invoking bank guarantees to recover Reliance Communications’ latest spectrum dues and is set to issue a notice asking why the airwaves shouldn’t be withdrawn. (ET)

Financials - RBI said State Bank of India (SBIN IS), ICICI Bank (ICICIBC IC) and HDFC Bank (HDFCB IS) will have to comply with additional capital requirement norms by April 1 as the banks continue to remain 'too big to fail' lenders. (ET)

BoJ keeps monetary policy settings unchanged as expected with NIRP held at -0.10% and 10yr JGB target at around 0%, lowers assessment on exports and output also as expected
content:
Says:

  • Maintains forward guidance of keeping rates at current extremely low levels for extended period.
  • BoJ decision of QQE with YCC control made by 7-2 vote (unchanged)
  • Japan economy likely to continue expanding moderately despite effects of overseas slowdown.
  • Exports showing some weakness recently and that output showing some weakness but is rising moderately as a trend.
  • Expects exports likely to remain weak for some time but remain on moderate rising trend.

subject: Chinese Premier Li says China faces new downward pressure but adds will not let growth slip out of reasonable range and that China's economic growth of 6.6% was hard-won
ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Sentiment improves in Asia as Trump touts China trade news in 3-4 weeks
content:
Asia stocks trade positive after the region shrugged off the negative lead from US where sentiment was subdued by growth and trade concerns following the recent discouraging data from China and with the Trump-Xi summit said to be delayed to April. ASX 200 (+0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.1%) are both higher but with Australia subdued as weakness in mining names and financials offset the gains in energy and telecoms, while the Japanese benchmark outperforms as it coat-tails on currency moves. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.9%) are also jubilant as overnight trade-related news flow spurs optimism including comments from President Trump that we will have news regarding a China trade deal in the next 3-4 weeks and although he included a ‘one way or the other’ caveat, he suggested that people will be talking about it for a long time and that China has been very reasonable. In addition, China has also contributed to the trade hopes after the NPC approved Foreign Investment law reforms dealing with forced tech transfers and IP theft which is seen as an attempt to appease US concerns.

In FX markets, the greenback is uneventful with the DXY stuck within the prior US session’s tight range amid a mixed picture across its major counterparts, with EUR/USD attempting to nurse losses after finding support around the 1.3000 level and with GBP/USD subdued as it takes a breather following this week’s parliamentary bedlam. In addition, the latest reports suggest Attorney General Cox is attempting to win over Tory Brexiteers and the DUP with new legal advice that Britain will be able to break off from the backstop under terms of the Vienna Convention, which follows parliamentary approval of the government's motion to extend the Article 50 process. Elsewhere, antipodeans are marginally positive as they benefit from their high-beta characteristics, as well as the improved risk tone which has also helped validate Gotobi demand advocates for USD/JPY.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are relatively flat as focus centres on riskier assets and with participants awaiting the BoJ policy announcement.

PRE-MARKET CHINESE  STOCK NEWS: US President Trump said we will have news on China trade deal in the next 3-4 weeks
content:
AIA Group (1299 HK) - Co. FY18 oper. profit USD 5.3bln vs. Prev. USD 4.6bln Y/Y, while new business value rose 22% Y/Y vs. Exp. 19% increase. (Newswires)

China Aoyuan Property (3883 HK) - Co. says Aoyuan Healthy Life IPO final offer price is at HKD 3.66/Shr. (Newswires)

China Star Entertainment (326 HK) - Co. issues profit alert in which it sees a substantial increase in FY profit. (Newswires)

Sands China (1928 HK) - Co. parent Las Vegas Sands (LVS) has settled its Macau dispute. (Newswires)

Other News - China may set up a Deposit Insurance Agency in the near-term. (Newswires)

NPC - Chinese Premier Li to deliver closing remarks from the NPC. (Newswires)

Trade Related

- US President Trump said he cannot say if the US will strike a final deal with China although talks are going very well. Furthermore, Trump later commented that we will have news on China trade deal in the next 3-4 weeks and will probably know then about possible trade deal with China, while he added China has been very responsible and very reasonable.

- Chinese Vice Premier Liu He conducted a phone call with US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and Trade Representative Lighthizer in which China and US were said to have made further substantive progress on trade discussions. In related news, there had been earlier reports that Treasury Secretary Mnuchin that is pleased with progress on trade talks with China and expects elements of Chinese trade talks to be resolved in the near future. (Newswires/CNBC)

- China and US are said to delay Trump-Xi meeting until April as according to sources, while there were later source reports that China is proposing tying in an official state visit by President Xi to a US trade deal. Separately, White House expects a significant market pop with a significant China trade deal and advisors reportedly have said the Dow could pop 2,000 points according to Fox's Gasparino. (Newswires)

Data Recap - Hong Kong Industrial Production (Q4) Y/Y1.3% (Prev. 1.2%) - Hong Kong PPI (Q4) Y/Y 0.3% (Prev. 0.1%)
